subject: CIPA lawsuits now targeting small business website owners throughout the US
preview: TL;DR: privacy lawsuits are now being filed against small business website owners (including one person companies) located outside of California for non-compliance with CIPA. The damages being sought

action.text: Rica Rosario Valencia marked as Closed

full_threads.body:
TL;DR: privacy lawsuits are now being filed against small business website owners (including one person companies) located outside of California for non-compliance with CIPA. The damages being sought under these lawsuits start at $50,000. To avoid these potential lawsuits and fees, add an opt-in consent banner to your website (provided with each Termageddon license). We have updated our overview of CIPA along with pre-written email assets for you to review and consider sharing with your clients. We have a handful of other updates at the bottom of this email (including a flash sale, and more).

Fellow agency partners,

Since our original post covering the recent rise in CIPA lawsuits, we have had several additional partners reach out to us, informing us that they too have small business clients (not using Termageddon), located outside of California, who have also received these demand letters.

We have heard of multiple one-person website owners receiving demand letters for $50,000 (or more). It's also a bit frustrating, knowing that this 30-year-old privacy law, originally intended for phone tracking regulation, is now being used against website owners, without the site owners having any idea that this law even exists.

Whatever the case, I think it's best that we provide you with everything we know so far, so that you can make the best decision for you and your clients.

What is CIPA (and what web agencies need to know about CIPA)
Here's what we know so far:
  1. CIPA is a 30-year-old privacy law originally intended to protect Californians from being monitored/tracked by third parties when on phone calls.
  2. A new stream of lawsuits has emerged, where attorneys are suing business owners (both large and small), due to their website being non-compliant with CIPA.
  3. Lawsuits are being filed against website owners for using third party tracking technologies (ad pixels, IP intelligence tools, etc.) without first getting consent from California-based website visitors
  4. This law can apply to any website owner (small business, large business, non-profit, etc.), regardless of where the owner/business is located.
  5. We are aware of multiple one person small business owners that have received these letters who are located both in California as well as other US states. Larger companies, including CNN, StitchFix, and the LA Times, have also been sued under this law.
  6. The damages being sought under these lawsuits appear to start at $50,000.
  7. The smallest settlement amount we are aware of is $6,500 (not including attorneys fees).
  8. Roughly 50% of the lawsuits are being dismissed by Judges. The other 50% are proceeding to Court (and we are waiting to hear the outcome). The cost to simply present a case to a Judge, however, can still be expensive (estimated at approximately $7,500 or more).
  9. We know that lawsuits have been filed against website owners for using the Facebook (Meta) Pixel, as well as IP Intelligence tools, without first getting consent from website visitors (from California). We believe additional lawsuits will be filed for websites using other third party tracking technologies (without consent) as well, including 3rd party video embeds, analytics/heatmap tracking tools, and more.
  10. A CCPA/CPRA opt-out banner is NOT compatible for complying with CIPA because users are opted into third party tracking technologies by default. Termageddon is still the only generator offering a consent banner that can cover both CIPA and CCPA/CPRA.


What can web agencies do about this?

Educate clients about this new trend, and offer a solution. You are welcome to use the pre-written email copy we put together discussing how to avoid these CIPA lawsuits. The good news is that after properly installing an opt-in consent banner (to block third party scripts that track/monitor site visitors), you've set up compatibility for CIPA (and if you're building WordPress websites, our plugin's geolocation feature allows you to hide the consent popup for visitors from other US states).

Also, for future clients, consider having them sign a website policies waiver if you have not done so already. First and foremost, this waiver helps protect you with documentation, ensuring clients understand that it is their responsibility to comply with laws associated with their business and website. The waiver also helps provide education to clients about why policies (and consent solutions) are important, and it offers the client options for next steps. Consider using this free asset or have your attorney draft you one. What matters most is that you get a message out to clients before an issue arises for them.


We hope this email helps debrief you on this recent privacy trend, and if you have any questions, you are welcome to reply to this email or submit a ticket.

Thank you,
Team Termageddon
Special Offers and Notices:

FLASH SALE: 15pack [+$1,800/year more recurring revenue]
We typically do a one-day flash sale each year in the summer, however in lieu of these recent changes with CIPA, we've released the special for the remainder of this month.
  • $328.90/year for 15 licenses. Renews at same price.
  • Resell each license at $120/yr (plus a recommended $100-$200 setup fee)
  • Cover your cost with just three clients signing up (most agencies report 80% or more of new clients signing up with Termageddon when they sign the website policies waiver prior to site launch).
  • Free swag item from shop.termageddon.com

The 15pack is now available in your Termageddon account (under "Hello" -> "Billing" -> "Buy" -> "Buy in Bulk"). Questions? Reply to this email!

Termageddon's President selected to be the ABA's representative to the United Nations
Donata was recently appointed by the President of the American Bar Association (ABA) to be its representative to the United Nations' Economic and Social Council, where she will be advocating for privacy rights for citizens of other nations and developing countries. We are quite proud of Donata and all that she does for the privacy industry!

Reminder: complimentary onboarding available for affiliate program
If reselling is not of interest to you, our affiliate program offers a complimentary onboarding service, where we personally walk your customers through the purchase and policy generation process (and then share the license with your partner account so you can grab the embed codes). This has become quite popular with our agency partners who want clients to pay Termageddon directly (and then we pay the partner recurring commissions)

How to introduce clients to privacy (blog post)
Privacy regulations are a new trend in our industry, and it can feel a bit overwhelming when initially communicating its importance to new clients. To help, we wrote up this article: "How to introduce clients to privacy.".

Updated US Website Policies Waiver
We have updated the US Website Policies Waiver to address the growing number of privacy lawsuits being filed for non-compliance with CIPA.
